speaker: Viral image
vclaim: He says you can identify pepper sex with "pumps."
date: stated on August 26, 2019 in a post on Facebook:
title: Pepper doesn't have sex.
text: In the great garden of life, we are here in Polyte Fruitte doing our best to remove lies. The allegations we make are often political. But this one is about pepper bells. "Pepper turns to check their sex" begins on August 26, Facebook, which shows the bottom of two green peppers. "Who have four bumps are females and who have three bumps are males. Female peppers are full of seeds, but sweeter and better to eat raw food, and males better to cook. I didn't know that." Neither do we. This article was referred to as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its news broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) This is because "this is a garden legend," according to the guidance department of Oregon State University. The distinguished fact-finding bloggers mentioned on January 10, 2021 in the story of "The Rebel Law - General Flynn will be appointed Vice-President." By Samantha Buterman: January 11, 2021, all pepper fruits are "whites fixed with seeds formed after pollination," Oso said in Q & A. These seeds can form new pepper plants. The bumps are mainly related to diversity and growing conditions. The butcher's pepper is sweeter, not female. That's why red peppers are sweeter than green peppers. We're assessing this wrong Facebook post.
